text: But seek ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you.
text_kjv: But seek ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you.
text_niv: But seek first his kingdom and his righteousness, and all these things will be given to you as well.
text_esv: But seek first the kingdom of God and his righteousness, and all these things will be added to you.
text_nlt: Seek the Kingdom of God above all else, and live righteously, and he will give you everything you need.
text_msg: Steep your life in God-reality, God-initiative, God-provisions. Don't worry about missing out. You'll find all your everyday human concerns will be met.
text_nasb: 'But seek first His kingdom and His righteousness, and all these things will be added to you.
context: Matthew 6:33 comes from Jesus's Sermon on the Mount, delivered early in His ministry around 28 AD. This sermon, recorded in Matthew chapters 5-7, represents Jesus's most comprehensive teaching on kingdom living. The immediate context is Matthew 6:19-34, which addresses materialism, money, and worry. Jesus had just taught about storing treasures in heaven rather than earth (6:19-21), serving God rather than money (6:24), and not worrying about material needs like food and clothing (6:25-32). He pointed to birds and flowers as examples of God's provision for His creation. The historical setting matters: Jesus's audience lived under Roman occupation, with heavy taxation and economic oppression. Many struggled with poverty. The Jewish religious system had become obsessed with external observance and material blessing as signs of God's favor. Into this context, Jesus presents a radically different priority system. The 'Gentiles' Jesus mentions (verse 32) refers to pagans who didn't know God and therefore anxiously pursued material security as their ultimate concern. Jesus contrasts His followers with this anxious materialism. The verse serves as both the climax and solution to the section on worry - instead of anxiously pursuing provisions, seek God's kingdom, and provision will follow.
meaning: The Greek text of Matthew 6:33 contains crucial nuances. 'But seek ye first' uses 'zeteo' (seek), meaning to search for, strive after, desire earnestly. This isn't passive waiting but active pursuit. 'First' (proton) indicates priority - not just chronologically but in importance. What you seek first reveals what you truly value and where you place ultimate trust. 'The kingdom of God' refers to God's reign and rule - His authority, His values, His purposes taking precedence in your life. It's not just a future place (heaven) but a present reality of living under God's kingship. Seeking the kingdom means aligning yourself with God's agenda, submitting to His authority, and participating in His redemptive purposes in the world. 'And his righteousness' adds a second object of pursuit. Righteousness (dikaiosune) can mean both right standing before God (justification) and right living before God (sanctification). The context suggests both - seeking to be made righteous through Christ and to live righteously according to God's standards. This contrasts with the superficial righteousness of the Pharisees Jesus critiqued earlier in the sermon. Seeking God's righteousness means hungering for genuine holiness, not just external religious performance. 'And all these things shall be added unto you' is the promise. 'These things' refers back to the material needs mentioned earlier - food, drink, clothing, basic necessities. 'Shall be added' (prostithemi) means to be placed beside, to be given in addition. The promise is that God will provide these necessities when you prioritize His kingdom. It's not that kingdom-seekers never experience need, but that God takes responsibility for provision when you take responsibility for prioritizing His kingdom. The logic is clear: if you seek God's kingdom first, trusting Him for provision, He will ensure you have what you need to continue serving His purposes.
application: Living out Matthew 6:33 requires examining what you actually seek first. It's easy to say we seek God's kingdom while our time, energy, and decisions reveal we're actually seeking financial security, career success, relationships, comfort, or approval. Practically, ask: What occupies my thoughts? What do I worry about? Where does my time go? What drives my major decisions? These reveal what you're really seeking first. If you're consumed with building wealth, your career, or your image while giving God leftover time and energy, you're not seeking His kingdom first. Reordering priorities means making conscious choices: choosing work that aligns with God's kingdom purposes over work that only maximizes income; giving generously to kingdom causes even when finances are tight; spending time in prayer and Scripture even when busy; making decisions based on God's values rather than worldly success metrics. Second, seeking God's righteousness means prioritizing holiness and Christlikeness over comfort or convenience. It means confronting sin patterns in your life rather than tolerating them. It means pursuing spiritual growth through disciplines like prayer, Bible study, fellowship, and service. Third, this verse provides the antidote to material anxiety. When you worry about finances, provision, or security, redirect that energy to seeking God's kingdom. Instead of obsessing over 'How will I make ends meet?' focus on 'How can I advance God's kingdom today?' Paradoxically, those who stop making material security their god often find God provides more faithfully than when they were anxiously striving. This isn't prosperity gospel - you might not get wealth - but you'll get what you need. Fourth, recognize that seeking God's kingdom often means sacrifice and costly choices. It might mean declining a lucrative job that would compromise your values, investing in ministry when you could save for retirement, or choosing time with family over career advancement. But the promise is that God will provide what you need to fulfill His purposes. Trust that promise more than you trust your own ability to secure provision.
prayer: Lord Jesus, You taught me to seek first Your kingdom and righteousness, but I confess that so often other things take priority. I seek financial security first, comfort first, success first, approval first - and I give You whatever is left over. Forgive me for this idolatry. I want to reorder my life around Your kingdom purposes. Help me to make decisions based on Your values rather than worldly standards. When I'm tempted to compromise Your standards for career advancement or financial gain, give me courage to choose Your righteousness instead. Teach me to use my time, money, gifts, and energy primarily to advance Your kingdom rather than build my own. I confess that I worry about provision and security, trying to control my own future instead of trusting You. Help me to believe Your promise that if I truly seek Your kingdom first, You will provide what I need. I don't need to anxiously strive for material security - I need to faithfully pursue Your purposes and trust You to provide. Transform my priorities, Lord, so that my life truly reflects kingdom-first living. In Your name, Amen.

faqs.answer: No - Scripture commends hard work (Proverbs 6:6-11, 2 Thessalonians 3:10) and wise planning (Proverbs 21:5). Seeking the kingdom first means your work and planning serve God's purposes rather than replace trust in Him. It's the difference between 'I work to provide while trusting God as my ultimate security' versus 'My security depends entirely on my work, so I must anxiously strive.' It means asking 'Does this job align with God's values and calling?' not just 'Does it pay well?' It means planning with submitted will - 'Lord willing' (James 4:13-15) rather than presuming control. Work hard, plan wisely, but do it as worship and kingdom service, not as anxious self-sufficiency.
faqs.question: Does seeking God's kingdom first mean I shouldn't work or plan for the future?

faqs.answer: This verse promises provision, not prosperity. 'All these things' refers to necessities (food, clothing), not luxuries or wealth. Many faithful kingdom-seekers throughout history have lived simply or experienced periods of material need while testifying to God's faithful provision. Paul faced hunger and need (Philippians 4:12) yet maintained God provided what he needed. Sometimes God's provision comes in unexpected ways - through community sharing, through contentment with less, through supernatural provision. The promise is that seeking God's kingdom first won't result in Him neglecting your needs - but His assessment of what you need may differ from yours. Also, examine whether you're genuinely seeking His kingdom first or just want His blessing on kingdom-second living.
faqs.question: What if I seek God's kingdom first but still struggle financially?

faqs.answer: Seeking the kingdom isn't just spiritual activities (though prayer and Bible study are essential). It means bringing kingdom values into every area of life. In work, ask how your job serves others and reflects God's glory, not just how it pays. In relationships, prioritize reconciliation, forgiveness, and love over self-protection and revenge. With money, give generously to kingdom causes rather than hoarding for personal security. In decisions, consult Scripture and pray for God's guidance rather than just doing what seems beneficial. Use your gifts to serve the church and advance the gospel. Speak truth when it's costly. Choose character development over convenience. Seek the kingdom means asking 'What does King Jesus want?' before 'What do I want?'
faqs.question: How do I seek God's kingdom practically in daily life?

faqs.answer: The immediate context addresses material needs, but the principle applies broadly. Whatever you're tempted to seek first instead of God's kingdom - whether that's relationship success, health, reputation, comfort, or achievement - Jesus's command stands: seek His kingdom first, and trust Him with the rest. This doesn't mean neglecting those areas or being irresponsible. It means they can't be your ultimate priority or security. You seek a God-honoring relationship within the context of seeking His kingdom, not a relationship that replaces kingdom priority. You care for your health as a steward while trusting God as your ultimate security, not making health preservation your god. The question is always: what do you seek first?
faqs.question: Does this apply to non-material concerns like relationships and health?
